A peripheral blood smear shows decreased platelets, which are well granulated and larger than normal. Leukocyte and erythrocyte morphology are normal without any schistocytes. The serum lactate dehydrogenase, prothrombin time, activated partial thromboplastin time, and fibrinogen levels are normal. Hepatitis C virus and HIV test are negative. Which next steps is most appropriate for this patient?
response:
Start treatment for immune thrombocytopenia — begin high‑dose corticosteroids (eg, prednisone 1 mg/kg daily) and add IVIG if rapid platelet rise is needed or bleeding worsens; reserve platelet transfusion only for life‑threatening hemorrhage.

Reasoning: The presentation (isolated severe thrombocytopenia with mucocutaneous bleeding, normal coagulation tests, large platelets, normal RBC/WBC, no splenomegaly) is most consistent with acute primary ITP. Testing for platelet autoantibodies is insensitive and not required to make the clinical diagnosis; immediate therapy is indicated at a platelet count of 10,000/µL.

question: A previously healthy 20-year-old man reports a one-week history of easy bruising and bleeding from the gums when flossing his teeth. He has no other personal or family history of bleeding. He takes no medication and does not drink alcohol or use illicit drug. He seems somewhat anxious during the interview. His vital sign are normal. Examination of the oropharynx reveals blood around the gums and a few hemorrhagic bullous lesions on the mucosa. His skin shows numerous petechiae. There is no lymphadenopathy. The liver and spleen are not palpable. Laboratory testing reveals a platelet count of 10,000 per mm3 (reference range, 150,000–350,000), a hemoglobin level of 14 g/dL (13.5–17.5) with normal indices, and a leukocyte count of 7500 per mm3 (4500–11,000) with normal differential. A peripheral blood smear shows decreased platelets, which are well granulated and larger than normal. Leukocyte and erythrocyte morphology are normal without any schistocytes. The serum lactate dehydrogenase, prothrombin time, activated partial thromboplastin time, and fibrinogen levels are normal. Hepatitis C virus and HIV test are negative. Which next steps is most appropriate for this patient?
response:
Initiate high‑dose corticosteroids — e.g., dexamethasone 40 mg once daily for 4 days (or prednisone ~1 mg/kg daily), with IVIG added if more rapid platelet rise is needed or bleeding is severe.

Reasoning: This presentation (isolated severe thrombocytopenia to 10,000/µL, mucosal bleeding, petechiae, large platelets, normal WBC/RBC/coagulation, no splenomegaly) is most consistent with immune thrombocytopenia (ITP). Diagnosis is clinical and treatment should not be delayed for platelet‑antibody testing. First‑line therapy for symptomatic or very low platelets is corticosteroids; IVIG is used when a faster response is required or bleeding is significant. Platelet transfusion is reserved for life‑threatening hemorrhage.

question: A previously healthy 20-year-old man reports a one-week history of easy bruising and bleeding from the gums when flossing his teeth. He has no other personal or family history of bleeding. He takes no medication and does not drink alcohol or use illicit drug. He seems somewhat anxious during the interview. His vital sign are normal. Examination of the oropharynx reveals blood around the gums and a few hemorrhagic bullous lesions on the mucosa. His skin shows numerous petechiae. There is no lymphadenopathy. The liver and spleen are not palpable. Laboratory testing reveals a platelet count of 10,000 per mm3 (reference range, 150,000–350,000), a hemoglobin level of 14 g/dL (13.5–17.5) with normal indices, and a leukocyte count of 7500 per mm3 (4500–11,000) with normal differential. A peripheral blood smear shows decreased platelets, which are well granulated and larger than normal. Leukocyte and erythrocyte morphology are normal without any schistocytes. The serum lactate dehydrogenase, prothrombin time, activated partial thromboplastin time, and fibrinogen levels are normal. Hepatitis C virus and HIV test are negative. Which next steps is most appropriate for this patient?
response:
This presentation is most consistent with immune thrombocytopenic purpura (isolated severe thrombocytopenia with large platelets, normal coagulation and other cell lines). He needs urgent therapy.

Start high‑dose corticosteroids (eg, oral prednisone) and give IV immunoglobulin for a rapid rise in platelets because his count is 10,000/mm3 with mucosal bleeding. Do not routinely transfuse platelets unless life‑threatening hemorrhage. Bone marrow biopsy is not required now unless atypical features or failure to respond.

question: A 19-year-old male presents to the primary care clinic with complaints of muscle cramping and generalized weakness that have persisted since his annual physical examination three months ago. He denies any factor that alleviate or exacerbate his symptom. The patient has no known medical or psychiatric history but began an intensive weight-lifting regimen approximately one year ago. During the visit, he appears calm but displays occasional irritability. His vital sign are as follows: temperature 36.6°C (97.9°F), pulse 75/min, respirations 16/min, blood pressure 115/75 mmHg, and body mass index (BMI) 19.0 kg/m². Physical examination reveals a thin, alert young male in no acute distress. Musculoskeletal examination shows increased muscle tone and vascularity in the upper extremities compared to three months ago. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal examinations are normal. Laboratory results show a serum magnesium level of 1.1 mEq/L and a serum phosphorous level of 2.5 mg/dL. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
response:
Most appropriate next step: obtain a 12‑lead ECG.

Reasoning: his serum magnesium (1.1 mEq/L) is severely low and predisposes to cardiac conduction abnormalities (prolonged QT, torsades). Before/while replacing magnesium you should assess for arrhythmia and monitor cardiac rhythm. Also check and correct potassium and calcium and give IV magnesium sulfate if ECG changes or significant symptoms.

question: A 19-year-old male presents to the primary care clinic with complaints of muscle cramping and generalized weakness that have persisted since his annual physical examination three months ago. He denies any factor that alleviate or exacerbate his symptom. The patient has no known medical or psychiatric history but began an intensive weight-lifting regimen approximately one year ago. During the visit, he appears calm but displays occasional irritability. His vital sign are as follows: temperature 36.6°C (97.9°F), pulse 75/min, respirations 16/min, blood pressure 115/75 mmHg, and body mass index (BMI) 19.0 kg/m². Physical examination reveals a thin, alert young male in no acute distress. Musculoskeletal examination shows increased muscle tone and vascularity in the upper extremities compared to three months ago. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal examinations are normal. Laboratory results show a serum magnesium level of 1.1 mEq/L and a serum phosphorous level of 2.5 mg/dL. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
response:
Conclusion: Give magnesium replacement — start IV magnesium sulfate for acute symptomatic hypomagnesemia (Mg 1.1 mEq/L).  

Reasoning: His muscle cramping/weakness and irritability are consistent with symptomatic hypomagnesemia (normal ~1.7–2.2 mEq/L). Levels ≤1.2 mEq/L with symptoms warrant IV magnesium (eg, 1–2 g MgSO4 IV over 15–60 min, then maintenance/PO as indicated), monitor renal function and ECG, and correct associated electrolytes (K+, Ca2+, phosphate) and investigate underlying cause. EMG/referral is not the appropriate next step.

question: A 19-year-old male presents to the primary care clinic with complaints of muscle cramping and generalized weakness that have persisted since his annual physical examination three months ago. He denies any factor that alleviate or exacerbate his symptom. The patient has no known medical or psychiatric history but began an intensive weight-lifting regimen approximately one year ago. During the visit, he appears calm but displays occasional irritability. His vital sign are as follows: temperature 36.6°C (97.9°F), pulse 75/min, respirations 16/min, blood pressure 115/75 mmHg, and body mass index (BMI) 19.0 kg/m². Physical examination reveals a thin, alert young male in no acute distress. Musculoskeletal examination shows increased muscle tone and vascularity in the upper extremities compared to three months ago. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal examinations are normal. Laboratory results show a serum magnesium level of 1.1 mEq/L and a serum phosphorous level of 2.5 mg/dL. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
response:
Give IV magnesium (magnesium sulfate) promptly and place on cardiac monitoring/obtain an ECG.  

Reason: his Mg2+ of 1.1 mEq/L is markedly low and explains his muscle cramps/weakness/irritability; symptomatic or severe hypomagnesemia should be repleted IV (and monitored because of risk of arrhythmias). Recheck electrolytes and correct phosphate as indicated.

question: A 40-year-old South Asian male visits his primary care provider due to a chronic cough that worsens at night. He reports having this cough for several years, with worsening symptom over the past few months. He recently moved to the United States for construction work and has experienced a 10-pound weight loss in the last 3 months. He also notes darker stools, which he attributes to a Western diet. He denies difficulty swallowing, food getting stuck, or any family history of cancer. He drinks alcohol 1–2 times per week, has never smoked, and his vital sign are within normal limits: temperature 98.6°F (37°C), blood pressure 114/72 mmHg, pulse 82/min, and respirations 12/min. Physical examination reveals clear lungs bilaterally, a soft and non-distended abdomen, no tenderness to palpation, and present bowel sounds. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
response:
Most appropriate next step: refer for upper endoscopy (esophagogastroduodenoscopy, EGD) to evaluate for upper GI pathology.

Reasoning: Although chronic nocturnal cough can be caused by GERD, the unintended 10 lb weight loss and darker stools are alarm features (possible GI blood loss or malignancy) that warrant direct visualization/biopsy rather than an empiric PPI trial.

response:

question: A 53-year-old male visits his primary care provider due to central, dull chest pain that began 30 minutes ago while attempting to nap after lunch. He recalls experiencing a similar, milder pain last week while sleeping at night. He reports a mild cough over the past 2 weeks, which he attributes to a cold, along with a sour taste in his mouth. He denies difficulty swallowing or bad breath. His medical history includes hyperlipidemia, obesity, and type 2 diabetes, and his medication are atorvastatin and metformin. His family history includes myocardial infarction in his father at age 51 and breast cancer in his mother at age 70. On examination, his temperature is 98.4°F (36.8°C), blood pressure is 147/92 mmHg, pulse is 80/min, and respirations are 14/min. He appears slightly uncomfortable but is not diaphoretic, and his physical exam is otherwise unremarkable. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
response:
Conclusion: Obtain a 12‑lead ECG immediately (and start evaluation for acute coronary syndrome with serial troponins).  

Reasoning: Although the sour taste and nocturnal symptoms could suggest reflux, this patient has central chest pain at rest plus multiple cardiac risk factors (age, diabetes, hyperlipidemia, family history). Life‑threatening cardiac causes must be excluded before treating for GERD with a PPI. If the ECG/troponins are nondiagnostic, pursue serial troponins and further risk‑stratification.

response:
Obtain a 12‑lead ECG immediately (and send stat cardiac troponin); treat as possible acute coronary syndrome rather than empirically giving an H2 blocker.

Reason: his chest pain is central, exertion‑independent and occurred at rest/night (typical for ischemia), and he has multiple CAD risk factors (age, diabetes, hyperlipidemia, family history). ECG/troponin are required to rule in/out acute MI—treating presumptively for reflux with an H2 blocker could dangerously delay evaluation. (If ECG/troponin suggest ACS, give aspirin and follow ACS protocol.)

question: A 4-week-old male infant is brought to the pediatrician by his parents for a routine well-child visit. His mother reports that he was feeding well until about a week ago, when he started vomiting after breastfeeding. Despite increasing feeding frequency and reducing the volume of each feed, the vomiting has progressively worsened and now occurs after every feeding. The vomitus appears similar to breast milk. The mother, who is exclusively breastfeeding, is concerned about her child’s nutrition and prefers not to switch to formula. Two weeks ago, the infant was in the 75th percentile for weight and 70th percentile for height; now, he is in the 60th percentile for weight and 68th percentile for height. Vital sign include a temperature of 98.2°F (36.8°C), blood pressure of 58/37 mmHg, pulse of 144/min, and respirations of 34/min. Physical examination reveals dry mucous membranes, a soft and non-distended abdomen. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
response:
Most appropriate next step: begin immediate fluid resuscitation with isotonic IV fluids (eg, a 20 mL/kg normal saline bolus) and obtain serum electrolytes; stabilize the infant before diagnostic imaging or surgery.

Reasoning: The history (age, progressive nonbilious vomiting) suggests hypertrophic pyloric stenosis, but the infant is hypovolemic (dry mucous membranes, tachycardia, hypotension). Restoring intravascular volume and checking/correcting electrolytes (eg, hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis) is the priority; abdominal ultrasound to confirm pyloric stenosis is appropriate only after initial stabilization.

response:

Reasoning: this 4‑week‑old with progressive nonbilious vomiting, weight loss and signs of dehydration (tachycardia, low BP, dry mucous membranes) is most consistent with hypertrophic pyloric stenosis. Immediate stabilization and correction of volume/electrolyte derangements is required prior to diagnostic studies or pyloromyotomy. Empiric PPI is inappropriate for a likely obstructive process.

response:

If confirmed, correct dehydration and electrolyte abnormalities (eg, hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis) before definitive treatment (pyloromyotomy). A trial of PPI is not appropriate here.

question: A 33-year-old female patient is evaluated after her husband brings her to the physician due to a 2-month history of persistent sadness accompanied by sleep difficulties and increased appetite. Her history reveals similar episodes lasting 4 months each, occurring 9 months ago and 2 years ago. Between these episodes, she experienced periods of high energy and required minimal sleep (3 hours), often going extended periods without eating. She is employed as a stock market trader and received a promotion 5 months ago. She maintains social activities, including regular weekend yoga classes with friends. Mental status examination reveals blunted affect. She denies both suicidal ideation and illicit substance use. What is the most likely diagnosis?
response:
Most likely diagnosis: Bipolar II disorder.

Reasoning: She has recurrent major depressive episodes (each lasting months) and interspersed periods of hypomanic symptoms (increased energy, markedly decreased need for sleep, no marked impairment and even improved functioning with a promotion). That pattern—at least one hypomanic episode plus major depressive episodes without any full manic episode—meets criteria for bipolar II, not cyclothymic disorder.

question: A 33-year-old female patient is evaluated after her husband brings her to the physician due to a 2-month history of persistent sadness accompanied by sleep difficulties and increased appetite. response:
Most likely diagnosis: Bipolar II disorder.

Reasoning: She has recurrent major depressive episodes (months long) interspersed with distinct periods of elevated energy/decreased need for sleep consistent with hypomania that improved functioning (promotion, maintained social life) and without mania/psychosis. This meets bipolar II criteria. It is not rapid cycling bipolar disorder because she does not have ≥4 mood episodes in the past 12 months, and it is not cyclothymic disorder because she has clear major depressive episodes rather than only subsyndromal mood fluctuations.

response:

There is no evidence of full manic episodes (so not bipolar I), and the pattern does not meet rapid-cycling (≥4 mood episodes/12 months) or cyclothymia (symptoms here meet full major depressive episode criteria).

Cyclothymic disorder is less likely because it describes chronic, milder fluctuating symptoms that never meet full criteria for major depressive or hypomanic episodes — whereas this patient’s depressive episodes appear to meet full MDE criteria.

question: A 33-year-old female patient is evaluated after her husband brings her to the physician due to a 2-month history of persistent sadness accompanied by sleep difficulties and increased appetite. She has recurrent major depressive episodes (months long) with intervening hypomanic periods (increased energy, decreased need for sleep, increased goal-directed activity) but no history of full mania or psychosis; that pattern fits bipolar II rather than MDD, bipolar I, or cyclothymia.

question: A 52-year-old African American male presents to his primary care physician reporting leg swelling that started approximately two weeks ago without any identifiable trigger. He also mentions joint pain, headaches, frothy urine, and tingling in his fingers and toes, though he does not believe these symptom are related to the swelling. He denies shortness of breath, back pain, or skull pain. His medical history includes well-controlled rheumatoid arthritis, diabetes, and hypertension. On physical examination, there is 3+ pitting edema in both legs. A chest radiograph shows mild cardiac enlargement. Urinalysis reveals 3+ proteinuria and casts with a cross-like appearance under polarized light. Renal biopsy demonstrates a characteristic finding visible only under polarized light. Which is most associated with the likely cause of this patient’s edema?
response:
Conclusion: Elevated serum amyloid A (SAA) — i.e., reactive (AA) amyloidosis from chronic inflammation.

Brief reasoning: The biopsy finding of Congo red–positive deposits with apple‑green birefringence on polarized light is diagnostic of amyloid. In a patient with long‑standing rheumatoid arthritis, AA (secondary) amyloidosis from prolonged elevation of the acute‑phase reactant SAA causes nephrotic syndrome and edema. IL‑6 contributes to SAA production, but the most specific association is increased SAA/AA amyloid deposition.

question: A 52-year-old African American male presents to his primary care physician reporting leg swelling that started approximately two weeks ago without any identifiable trigger. He also mentions joint pain, headaches, frothy urine, and tingling in his fingers and toes, though he does not believe these symptom are related to the swelling. He denies shortness of breath, back pain, or skull pain. His medical history includes well-controlled rheumatoid arthritis, diabetes, and hypertension. Urinalysis reveals 3+ proteinuria and casts with a cross-like appearance under polarized light. Renal biopsy demonstrates a characteristic finding visible only under polarized light. Which is most associated with the likely cause of this patient’s edema?
response:
Conclusion: The edema is most likely from secondary (AA) renal amyloidosis due to his chronic rheumatoid arthritis — which is associated with elevated serum amyloid A (an acute‑phase reactant) and Congo‑red positive deposits showing apple‑green birefringence under polarized light.

Reasoning: Nephrotic picture (massive proteinuria, frothy urine, edema) in a patient with long‑standing inflammatory disease points to AA amyloid deposition in the kidney; Congo red/apple‑green birefringence is the polarized‑light biopsy finding. (The “Maltese cross” lipiduria reflects nephrotic syndrome but is not the diagnostic biopsy finding.)

question: A 52-year-old African American male presents to his primary care physician reporting leg swelling that started approximately two weeks ago without any identifiable trigger. Which is most associated with the likely cause of this patient’s edema?
response:
Conclusion: Elevated IL-6 (driving increased serum amyloid A) is the most associated finding.

Reasoning: The polarized‑light biopsy finding (Congo red apple‑green birefringence) indicates renal amyloid causing nephrotic syndrome. AA (secondary) amyloidosis occurs with chronic inflammatory diseases such as rheumatoid arthritis — IL‑6 (and IL‑1/TNF) upregulates hepatic serum amyloid A production, leading to AA amyloid deposition in the kidney.

question: A 52-year-old African American male presents to his primary care physician reporting leg swelling that started approximately two weeks ago without any identifiable trigger. He also mentions joint pain, headaches, frothy urine, and tingling in his fingers and toes, though he does not believe these symptom are related to the swelling. He denies shortness of breath, back pain, or skull pain. His medical history includes well-controlled rheumatoid arthritis, diabetes, and hypertension. On physical examination, there is 3+ pitting edema in both legs. A chest radiograph shows mild cardiac enlargement. Urinalysis reveals 3+ proteinuria and casts with a cross-like appearance under polarized light. Renal biopsy demonstrates a characteristic finding visible only under polarized light. Which is most associated with the likely cause of this patient’s edema?
response: Massive proteinuria → hypoalbuminemia → decreased plasma oncotic (colloid) pressure, causing fluid to shift into the interstitium (nephrotic‑syndrome–related edema).

question: A 2-year-old female patient presents with persistent cough and nasal congestion since birth that has not improved with treatment using albuterol, fluticasone, or loratadine. Her history includes one episode of pneumonia, though she maintains appropriate weight gain. Which diagnostic test would be most suitable to establish the diagnosis?
response:
Conclusion: Measure nasal nitric oxide (nNO) as the initial diagnostic test to screen for primary ciliary dyskinesia (PCD); if low, confirm with genetic testing and/or ciliary biopsy (high‑speed video microscopy and/or electron microscopy).

Reasoning: Chronic nasal congestion and daily wet cough since birth with poor response to bronchodilator/steroid/antihistamine strongly suggests PCD. nNO is a noninvasive, sensitive screening test (low in PCD, can be done in young children using tidal‑breathing methods). Genetic testing and ciliary ultrastructural studies then serve as confirmatory tests; genetic testing alone can miss some cases, so it’s usually part of a confirmatory workup. (If you instead suspect cystic fibrosis, perform a sweat chloride test.)

question: A 2-year-old female patient presents with persistent cough and nasal congestion since birth that has not improved with treatment using albuterol, fluticasone, or loratadine. Her history includes one episode of pneumonia, though she maintains appropriate weight gain. Which diagnostic test would be most suitable to establish the diagnosis?
response:
Conclusion: Suspect primary ciliary dyskinesia (PCD). The most appropriate first diagnostic test is nasal nitric oxide (nNO) measurement (low in PCD); confirm the diagnosis with genetic testing and/or nasal brush biopsy for ciliary analysis (high‑speed video microscopy and transmission electron microscopy).

Reasoning: Chronic nasal congestion and persistent cough from birth with recurrent infections and normal growth fit PCD. HRCT can show bronchiectasis but is often normal early and is not diagnostic. nNO is a noninvasive, high‑sensitivity screening test; a low result should prompt confirmatory testing with a PCD gene panel and/or ciliary ultrastructure/function testing at a specialized center.

question: A 2-year-old female patient presents with persistent cough and nasal congestion since birth that has not improved with treatment using albuterol, fluticasone, or loratadine. Her history includes one episode of pneumonia, though she maintains appropriate weight gain. Which diagnostic test would be most suitable to establish the diagnosis?
response:
Measure nasal nitric oxide (low in primary ciliary dyskinesia) as the initial diagnostic test, with confirmation by ciliary ultrastructure analysis (nasal brush biopsy with electron microscopy) or genetic testing.

Reasoning: chronic wet cough and lifelong nasal congestion since birth with recurrent infections strongly suggests primary ciliary dyskinesia; nasal NO is a noninvasive screening test, and ciliary EM/genetic testing establishes the diagnosis.

question: A 2-year-old female patient presents with persistent cough and nasal congestion since birth that has not improved with treatment using albuterol, fluticasone, or loratadine. Her history includes one episode of pneumonia, though she maintains appropriate weight gain. Which diagnostic test would be most suitable to establish the diagnosis?
response:
No — the most suitable initial diagnostic test is a quantitative sweat chloride test (pilocarpine iontophoresis).

Reasoning: chronic respiratory symptoms from birth and recurrent pneumonia strongly suggest cystic fibrosis; the sweat chloride test is the gold‑standard diagnostic test. CFTR genetic testing is valuable as a confirmatory/adjunct test (or if sweat results are borderline) and for mutation identification, but sweat chloride is the primary diagnostic screen.

question: A 2-year-old female patient presents with persistent cough and nasal congestion since birth that has not improved with treatment using albuterol, fluticasone, or loratadine. Her history includes one episode of pneumonia, though she maintains appropriate weight gain. Which diagnostic test would be most suitable to establish the diagnosis?
response: This history (chronic wet cough and nasal congestion since birth, poor response to asthma/allergy meds, recurrent pneumonia with preserved growth) suggests primary ciliary dyskinesia. The most suitable initial diagnostic test is measurement of nasal nitric oxide (very low in PCD). Low values are then confirmed with ciliary ultrastructure analysis (electron microscopy/high‑speed video microscopy) or genetic testing.

question: An 18-year-old male presents for a follow-up evaluation two months after craniopharyngioma resection. The tumor was initially discovered during investigation of delayed puberty and panhypopituitarism. He reports feeling generally well but notes intermittent fevers reaching 39°C and increased appetite. His medication regimen includes: - Levothyroxine 112 μg daily - Hydrocortisone (20 mg morning, 10 mg afternoon) - Desmopressin nasal spray - Testosterone injections (intramuscular) Current examination reveals: - Temperature: 38.8°C - Heart rate: 97/min - Blood pressure: 129/88 mm Hg - BMI: 34.2 - Well-healed craniotomy scar without complications - No nuchal rigidity - Otherwise normal physical exam Laboratory finding are unremarkable except: - Sodium: 146 mEq/L (reference: 136-145) - TSH: 0.051 μU/mL (reference: 0.5-4.7) - Free T4: 1.8 ng/dL (reference: 0.8-1.8) Recent negative workup includes: - Two sets of blood cultures - Urinalysis and urine culture - CSF analysis - Chest radiograph - MRI head (showing expected post-surgical changes) What is the most likely etiology of this patient's fever?
response:
Most likely etiology: central (hypothalamic) fever from hypothalamic injury after craniopharyngioma resection.

Reasoning: He has postoperative features of hypothalamic damage (marked hyperphagia/obesity, DI requiring desmopressin) and persistent high fevers with exhaustive negative infectious workup and no systemic inflammatory signs. His low TSH with upper‑normal free T4 reflects levothyroxine replacement, not thyrotoxicosis (which would cause weight loss/tachycardia). Central thermoregulatory dysfunction after hypothalamic surgery is a diagnosis of exclusion and best explains this presentation.

question: An 18-year-old male presents for a follow-up evaluation two months after craniopharyngioma resection. The tumor was initially discovered during investigation of delayed puberty and panhypopituitarism. He reports feeling generally well but notes intermittent fevers reaching 39°C and increased appetite. His medication regimen includes: - Levothyroxine 112 μg daily - Hydrocortisone (20 mg morning, 10 mg afternoon) - Desmopressin nasal spray - Testosterone injections (intramuscular) Current examination reveals: - Temperature: 38.8°C - Heart rate: 97/min - Blood pressure: 129/88 mm Hg - BMI: 34.2 - Well-healed craniotomy scar without complications - No nuchal rigidity - Otherwise normal physical exam Laboratory finding are unremarkable except: - Sodium: 146 mEq/L (reference: 136-145) - TSH: 0.051 μU/mL (reference: 0.5-4.7) - Free T4: 1.8 ng/dL (reference: 0.8-1.8) Recent negative workup includes: - Two sets of blood cultures - Urinalysis and urine culture - CSF analysis - Chest radiograph - MRI head (showing expected post-surgical changes) What is the most likely etiology of this patient's fever?
response:
Most likely diagnosis: central fever from hypothalamic dysfunction (post‑craniopharyngioma/surgical injury), not levothyroxine overreplacement.

Why: infectious workup and imaging are negative, and craniopharyngiomas and their resection commonly damage the hypothalamic thermoregulatory center causing intermittent high fevers. He already has other signs of hypothalamic involvement (hyperphagia/obesity, panhypopituitarism). The thyroid data do not support frank thyrotoxicosis from overreplacement — in central pituitary disease TSH is unreliable, and his free T4 is only at the upper limit of normal (no classic hyperthyroid features such as weight loss, atrial fibrillation, tremor). Hydrocortisone/testosterone regimens are unlikely causes. 

Practical notes: continue to dose levothyroxine guided by free T4 (not TSH) and treat fevers/supportively; involve endocrinology and neurosurgery/neurology if fevers persist or other autonomic signs develop.

question: An 18-year-old male presents for a follow-up evaluation two months after craniopharyngioma resection. The tumor was initially discovered during investigation of delayed puberty and panhypopituitarism. He reports feeling generally well but notes intermittent fevers reaching 39°C and increased appetite. response:
Most likely: central (hypothalamic) fever from hypothalamic injury after craniopharyngioma resection — not levothyroxine overreplacement.

Why: infectious workup is repeatedly negative; timing after craniopharyngioma surgery and the new hyperphagia/obesity (BMI 34) point to hypothalamic damage causing both appetite and thermoregulatory dysregulation. The slight hypernatremia and need for desmopressin also support hypothalamic/pituitary axis dysfunction. Free T4 is only at the upper normal limit and TSH is not a reliable marker in pituitary disease, so overt thyrotoxicosis from overreplacement is less likely. Central fever from hypothalamic injury is a well‑recognized, noninfectious cause in this setting.

question: An 18-year-old male presents for a follow-up evaluation two months after craniopharyngioma resection. The tumor was initially discovered during investigation of delayed puberty and panhypopituitarism. He reports feeling generally well but notes intermittent fevers reaching 39°C and increased appetite. His medication regimen includes: - Levothyroxine 112 μg daily - Hydrocortisone (20 mg morning, 10 mg afternoon) - Desmopressin nasal spray - Testosterone injections (intramuscular) Current examination reveals: - Temperature: 38.8°C - Heart rate: 97/min - Blood pressure: 129/88 mm Hg - BMI: 34.2 - Well-healed craniotomy scar without complications - No nuchal rigidity - Otherwise normal physical exam Laboratory finding are unremarkable except: - Sodium: 146 mEq/L (reference: 136-145) - TSH: 0.051 μU/mL (reference: 0.5-4.7) - Free T4: 1.8 ng/dL (reference: 0.8-1.8) Recent negative workup includes: - Two sets of blood cultures - Urinalysis and urine culture - CSF analysis - Chest radiograph - MRI head (showing expected post-surgical changes) What is the most likely etiology of this patient's fever?
response:
Hypothalamic dysfunction (central fever from hypothalamic injury) is most likely.

Reasoning: craniopharyngioma resection commonly injures the hypothalamus and produces impaired thermoregulation (sterile/central fever), hyperphagia with weight gain, and dysregulation of osmoregulation (mild hypernatremia). The infectious workup is negative, arguing against sepsis. Although TSH is suppressed, free T4 is at the upper limit of normal and the patient lacks the tachycardia, weight loss, or agitation of thyrotoxicosis/thyroid storm, so levothyroxine overreplacement is less likely to explain his intermittent fevers.

question: An 18-year-old male presents for a follow-up evaluation two months after craniopharyngioma resection. The tumor was initially discovered during investigation of delayed puberty and panhypopituitarism. He reports feeling generally well but notes intermittent fevers reaching 39°C and increased appetite. His medication regimen includes: - Levothyroxine 112 μg daily - Hydrocortisone (20 mg morning, 10 mg afternoon) - Desmopressin nasal spray - Testosterone injections (intramuscular) Current examination reveals: - Temperature: 38.8°C - Heart rate: 97/min - Blood pressure: 129/88 mm Hg - BMI: 34.2 - Well-healed craniotomy scar without complications - No nuchal rigidity - Otherwise normal physical exam Laboratory finding are unremarkable except: - Sodium: 146 mEq/L (reference: 136-145) - TSH: 0.051 μU/mL (reference: 0.5-4.7) - Free T4: 1.8 ng/dL (reference: 0.8-1.8) Recent negative workup includes: - Two sets of blood cultures - Urinalysis and urine culture - CSF analysis - Chest radiograph - MRI head (showing expected post-surgical changes) What is the most likely etiology of this patient's fever?
response: Most likely iatrogenic thyrotoxicosis from excessive levothyroxine replacement. The very low TSH with high‑normal free T4 in the setting of new hypermetabolic symptoms (fever, increased appetite, mild tachycardia) and a negative infectious workup points to over‑replacement. Management is to reduce the levothyroxine dose and recheck TFTs.

question: A 59-year-old woman comes to the physician because of increasing shortness of breath, malaise, and a cough for the past week. The cough is productive of a small volume of green sputum. Over the past 9 months, she was hospitalized twice for left lower lobe pneumonia. Her medical history is otherwise unremarkable. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 36 years. Her temperature is 39.3°C (102.7°F), pulse is 103/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 132/84 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 89%. Auscultation of the lungs discloses end-expiratory wheezes, and decreased breath sounds and crackles are heard at the left lung base. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. Chest x-ray shows a homogeneous area of increased opacification in the left lower lobe. Which is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?
response:
No — the most appropriate next diagnostic step is a chest CT (contrast-enhanced) to evaluate for an endobronchial or parenchymal mass causing recurrent, focal (left lower lobe) pneumonias.  

Reason: Recurrent pneumonia in the same lobe in a long-term smoker suggests postobstructive pneumonia from an obstructing lesion (eg, bronchogenic carcinoma); CT is more sensitive than chest x‑ray to detect masses and airway obstruction. Echocardiography is not indicated given no clinical signs of cardiac disease. If CT suggests an endobronchial lesion, proceed to bronchoscopy with biopsy.

question: A 59-year-old woman comes to the physician because of increasing shortness of breath, malaise, and a cough for the past week. The cough is productive of a small volume of green sputum. Over the past 9 months, she was hospitalized twice for left lower lobe pneumonia. Her medical history is otherwise unremarkable. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 36 years. Her temperature is 39.3°C (102.7°F), pulse is 103/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 132/84 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 89%. Auscultation of the lungs discloses end-expiratory wheezes, and decreased breath sounds and crackles are heard at the left lung base. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. Chest x-ray shows a homogeneous area of increased opacification in the left lower lobe. Which is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?
response:
Obtain a contrast-enhanced CT scan of the chest.

Reasoning: Recurrent, localized pneumonia in the same lobe strongly suggests an underlying obstructing lesion (eg, endobronchial carcinoma), bronchiectasis, or other structural abnormality. Chest CT is the best noninvasive next test to identify a mass/airway obstruction and to guide further management (eg, bronchoscopy with biopsy if a lesion is seen).

question: A 59-year-old woman comes to the physician because of increasing shortness of breath, malaise, and a cough for the past week. The cough is productive of a small volume of green sputum. Over the past 9 months, she was hospitalized twice for left lower lobe pneumonia. Her medical history is otherwise unremarkable. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 36 years. response:
Obtain a contrast-enhanced chest CT.

Reason: Recurrent pneumonia confined to the same lobe suggests an underlying obstructing lesion (eg bronchogenic carcinoma with postobstructive pneumonia) or anatomic abnormality; CT is the best next test to look for a mass, bronchial obstruction, or bronchiectasis. If CT shows a suspicious lesion, proceed to bronchoscopy with biopsy for tissue diagnosis.

question: A 59-year-old woman comes to the physician because of increasing shortness of breath, malaise, and a cough for the past week. The cough is productive of a small volume of green sputum. Over the past 9 months, she was hospitalized twice for left lower lobe pneumonia. Her medical history is otherwise unremarkable. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 36 years. Her temperature is 39.3°C (102.7°F), pulse is 103/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 132/84 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 89%. Auscultation of the lungs discloses end-expiratory wheezes, and decreased breath sounds and crackles are heard at the left lung base. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. Chest x-ray shows a homogeneous area of increased opacification in the left lower lobe. Which is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?
response:
CT scan of the chest with contrast is the most appropriate next step.

Reason: Recurrent pneumonia localized to the same lobe suggests an anatomic obstruction (eg, endobronchial tumor, bronchial stenosis) or focal structural disease; chest CT best evaluates for a mass, airway obstruction, abscess, or bronchiectasis and guides bronchoscopic biopsy if needed. Echocardiography is not indicated here because the presentation and focal findings point to pulmonary, not cardiac, disease.

question: A 59-year-old woman comes to the physician because of increasing shortness of breath, malaise, and a cough for the past week. The cough is productive of a small volume of green sputum. Over the past 9 months, she was hospitalized twice for left lower lobe pneumonia. Her medical history is otherwise unremarkable. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 36 years. Her temperature is 39.3°C (102.7°F), pulse is 103/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 132/84 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 89%. Auscultation of the lungs discloses end-expiratory wheezes, and decreased breath sounds and crackles are heard at the left lung base. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. Chest x-ray shows a homogeneous area of increased opacification in the left lower lobe. Which is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?
response: Obtain a chest CT (contrast-enhanced CT of the chest) to evaluate for an obstructing endobronchial lesion or mass (eg, bronchogenic carcinoma) causing recurrent focal pneumonia.

question: A 30-year-old primigravida at 30 weeks' gestation presents to the emergency department with worsening upper abdominal pain over the past hour. She reports initial dull stomach pain approximately 6 hours ago that has progressed and localized to the upper abdomen. She experienced one episode of emesis en route to the hospital. Her medical and family histories are unremarkable. She is in a monogamous relationship with her husband. She denies tobacco or alcohol use. Her only medication are folic acid and prenatal vitamins. Her vital sign show a temperature of 38.5°C (101.3°F), heart rate of 100/min, and blood pressure of 130/80 mm Hg. Physical examination reveals right upper quadrant tenderness but is otherwise normal. Laboratory finding are as follows: | Hemoglobin | 13.1 g/dL | | --- | --- | | Leukocyte count | 17,000/mm3 | | Serum | | | Urea nitrogen | 20 mg/dL | | Creatinine | 0.8 mg/dL | | Alkaline phosphatase | 79 U/L | | Bilirubin | | | Total | 1 mg/dL | | Direct | 0.3 mg/dL | Urinalysis demonstrates mild pyuria. What is the most likely diagnosis?
response:
Most likely diagnosis: acute appendicitis (appendix displaced upward by the gravid uterus).

Reasoning: classic course of periumbilical dull pain that localized over hours, fever and leukocytosis fit appendicitis. In late pregnancy the enlarged uterus pushes the appendix upward so pain can present in the right upper quadrant. Mild pyuria is commonly seen with appendicitis from adjacent inflammation and can mimic a UTI. Findings argue against acute cholangitis (no jaundice, only minimally elevated bilirubin, normal alkaline phosphatase). Imaging (RUQ/transabdominal ultrasound or MRI if ultrasound nondiagnostic) and surgical consultation are indicated.

response:

Reasoning: the history of initial vague periumbilical/epigastric pain that localizes over hours, fever, leukocytosis and vomiting is classic for appendicitis; in late pregnancy the enlarging uterus pushes the appendix upward so the pain localizes to the RUQ. Normal bilirubin/LFTs argue against biliary obstruction/acute fatty liver or HELLP, and pyuria can be seen with appendiceal inflammation (or from contamination) so a mild UA finding does not exclude appendicitis.

What is the most likely diagnosis?
response:
Acute appendicitis.

Reasoning: She had initial vague periumbilical/stomach pain that migrated and localized (now RUQ), with fever, leukocytosis and vomiting—classic for appendicitis. In pregnancy the enlarged uterus displaces the appendix upward so pain/localization can be in the RUQ. Mild pyuria can occur with appendiceal inflammation (sterile pyuria) and normal bilirubin/LFTs make acute cholecystitis/hepatitis less likely. Next steps: RUQ-focused ultrasound and, if inconclusive, MRI (preferred in pregnancy) for confirmation.

question: A 65-year-old male with a smoking history of 10 pack-years presents with progressive dyspnea and a dry cough that began approximately 8 months ago, coinciding with flooding in his apartment. He now experiences shortness of breath after walking two blocks or climbing one flight of stairs, whereas he previously had no such limitations. He has no pets at home. Physical examination reveals bilateral crackles on auscultation, with no other significant finding. Chest CT demonstrates diffuse centrilobular nodules with air trapping. Pulmonary function test show an FEV1/FVC ratio of 60%. What is the most appropriate next step in evaluation?
truth: Trial of living away from the residence
response:
The next step is bronchoscopy with bronchoalveolar lavage (and consideration of transbronchial biopsy) to look for lymphocytic alveolitis consistent with hypersensitivity pneumonitis.

Reason: The history of onset after apartment flooding, CT with diffuse centrilobular nodules and air‑trapping, and obstructive physiology strongly suggest subacute/chronic hypersensitivity pneumonitis. BAL lymphocytosis (and histology if needed) is the appropriate diagnostic test. Antigen avoidance (relocating) is important therapeutically but you should confirm the diagnosis first.

question: A 65-year-old male with a smoking history of 10 pack-years presents with progressive dyspnea and a dry cough that began approximately 8 months ago, coinciding with flooding in his apartment. He now experiences shortness of breath after walking two blocks or climbing one flight of stairs, whereas he previously had no such limitations. He has no pets at home. Physical examination reveals bilateral crackles on auscultation, with no other significant finding. Chest CT demonstrates diffuse centrilobular nodules with air trapping. Pulmonary function test show an FEV1/FVC ratio of 60%. What is the most appropriate next step in evaluation?
truth: Trial of living away from the residence
response:
Most appropriate next step: bronchoalveolar lavage (via bronchoscopy) to look for a lymphocytic alveolitis consistent with hypersensitivity pneumonitis.

Reasoning: the history of flooding (mold exposure), subacute onset, CT showing diffuse centrilobular nodules with air‑trapping (mosaic attenuation) and crackles point to hypersensitivity pneumonitis/small‑airway inflammatory disease rather than asthma. BAL demonstrating marked lymphocytosis supports the diagnosis and helps differentiate HP from other interstitial or obstructive processes; methacholine challenge is for asthma and would be neither specific nor the best next test here.

question: A 65-year-old male with a smoking history of 10 pack-years presents with progressive dyspnea and a dry cough that began approximately 8 months ago, coinciding with flooding in his apartment. response:

Reasoning: the subacute onset after apartment flooding, centrilobular nodules with air‑trapping on CT, crackles, and exposure history point to hypersensitivity pneumonitis/small‑airways inflammatory disease rather than asthma. BAL showing lymphocytosis (and transbronchial biopsy if needed) is the next diagnostic test to support the diagnosis.

question: A 65-year-old male with a smoking history of 10 pack-years presents with progressive dyspnea and a dry cough that began approximately 8 months ago, coinciding with flooding in his apartment. He now experiences shortness of breath after walking two blocks or climbing one flight of stairs, whereas he previously had no such limitations. He has no pets at home. Physical examination reveals bilateral crackles on auscultation, with no other significant finding. Chest CT demonstrates diffuse centrilobular nodules with air trapping. Pulmonary function test show an FEV1/FVC ratio of 60%. What is the most appropriate next step in evaluation?
truth: Trial of living away from the residence
response:
No — the most appropriate next step is a trial of antigen avoidance (living away from the flooded apartment).

Reasoning: the history of onset after apartment flooding, dry cough/dyspnea over months, CT with diffuse centrilobular nodules and air‑trapping are most consistent with hypersensitivity pneumonitis from mold exposure. Removing the patient from the suspected antigen source is both diagnostic and therapeutic. Methacholine challenge is used to diagnose asthma and would be low yield here. If symptoms do not improve after avoidance, pursue confirmatory testing (serum precipitins, BAL with lymphocytosis, and/or lung biopsy).

question: A 65-year-old male with a smoking history of 10 pack-years presents with progressive dyspnea and a dry cough that began approximately 8 months ago, coinciding with flooding in his apartment. He now experiences shortness of breath after walking two blocks or climbing one flight of stairs, whereas he previously had no such limitations. He has no pets at home. Physical examination reveals bilateral crackles on auscultation, with no other significant finding. Chest CT demonstrates diffuse centrilobular nodules with air trapping. Pulmonary function test show an FEV1/FVC ratio of 60%. What is the most appropriate next step in evaluation?
truth: Trial of living away from the residence
response: Suspect hypersensitivity pneumonitis from mold exposure. The next step is bronchoscopy with bronchoalveolar lavage (and transbronchial biopsy if indicated) to look for a lymphocytic BAL differential consistent with HP.

question: A 9-day-old male infant is brought to the clinic by his mother due to concerns of poor feeding and episodes of color changes. He was delivered full term via cesarean section for nonreassuring fetal heart tones, with an unremarkable nursery stay. Since discharge, he has been breastfeeding poorly, appearing fatigued and taking longer to feed. His mother reports that he "turns blue when crying," along with rapid breathing and occasional grunting. On examination, the infant has a heart rate of 165 beats per minute, normal blood pressure for his age, and oxygen saturations of 70% preductal and 68% postductal on room air. He appears cyanotic and fatigued, with tachypnea and subcostal retractions. A prominent apical impulse and a thrill are noted on palpation. Auscultation reveals a click after the first heart sound, a fixed, split second heart sound, and a 4/6 crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur heard loudest at the left upper sternal border, extending into diastole. His liver is palpable 2 cm below the costal margin, and bowel sounds are normal. Chest radiography shows normal heart size with decreased pulmonary vascularity and no focal consolidation. An electrocardiogram demonstrates sinus tachycardia, right axis deviation, a pure R wave >20 mm in lead V1, and inverted T waves in lead V4. Prostaglandin E1 is initiated. What is the most appropriate next step in management for this patient?
response:
Most appropriate next step: Obtain an urgent transthoracic echocardiogram (stat echocardiography).

Reasoning: You correctly started PGE1 to maintain ductal flow for a suspected ductal‑dependent, reduced‑pulmonary‑blood‑flow lesion. Before committing to an invasive therapy (eg, balloon pulmonary valvuloplasty vs surgical repair), you must define the anatomic lesion and severity with echocardiography. If the echo confirms critical valvular pulmonary stenosis, balloon valvuloplasty is the indicated next intervention.

His mother reports that he "turns blue when crying," along with rapid breathing and occasional grunting. On examination, the infant has a heart rate of 165 beats per minute, normal blood pressure for his age, and oxygen saturations of 70% preductal and 68% postductal on room air. He appears cyanotic and fatigued, with tachypnea and subcostal retractions. A prominent apical impulse and a thrill are noted on palpation. Auscultation reveals a click after the first heart sound, a fixed, split second heart sound, and a 4/6 crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur heard loudest at the left upper sternal border, extending into diastole. His liver is palpable 2 cm below the costal margin, and bowel sounds are normal. Chest radiography shows normal heart size with decreased pulmonary vascularity and no focal consolidation. An electrocardiogram demonstrates sinus tachycardia, right axis deviation, a pure R wave >20 mm in lead V1, and inverted T waves in lead V4. Prostaglandin E1 is initiated. What is the most appropriate next step in management for this patient?
response:
Most appropriate next step: obtain an urgent transthoracic echocardiogram to confirm the anatomy and degree of right‑sided outflow obstruction and guide definitive therapy.

Reasoning: the picture — cyanotic infant with low pre/postductal sats, decreased pulmonary vascularity on CXR, RV hypertrophy on ECG, and a left‑upper‑sternal systolic ejection murmur — is most consistent with tetralogy of Fallot (severe RV outflow obstruction/duct‑dependent pulmonary blood flow). Prostaglandin was appropriately started to maintain ductal patency; definitive management (surgical repair) requires echocardiographic anatomic delineation first to plan timing/type of repair or catheter intervention. If the baby were having an acute “tet spell,” immediate supportive measures (oxygen, knee‑to‑chest positioning, morphine, IV fluids and consideration of a beta‑blocker) would also be instituted while arranging urgent echo and cardiac surgery consultation.

response:
Obtain an urgent transthoracic echocardiogram and activate pediatric cardiology for definitive diagnostic evaluation and management planning.

Reasoning: this cyanotic, ductal-dependent presentation (low pre/postductal saturations, decreased pulmonary vascularity, RV hypertrophy/right‑axis on ECG) requires immediate imaging to define the lesion (e.g., tetralogy spectrum, critical pulmonic stenosis/atresia) so the team can decide on catheter intervention (balloon valvuloplasty or ductal stenting) versus surgical repair. Prostaglandin was appropriate to maintain pulmonary blood flow while awaiting echo and specialist input.

question: A 9-day-old male infant is brought to the clinic by his mother due to concerns of poor feeding and episodes of color changes. He was delivered full term via cesarean section for nonreassuring fetal heart tones, with an unremarkable nursery stay. Since discharge, he has been breastfeeding poorly, appearing fatigued and taking longer to feed. His mother reports that he "turns blue when crying," along with rapid breathing and occasional grunting. On examination, the infant has a heart rate of 165 beats per minute, normal blood pressure for his age, and oxygen saturations of 70% preductal and 68% postductal on room air. He appears cyanotic and fatigued, with tachypnea and subcostal retractions. A prominent apical impulse and a thrill are noted on palpation. Auscultation reveals a click after the first heart sound, a fixed, split second heart sound, and a 4/6 crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur heard loudest at the left upper sternal border, extending into diastole. His liver is palpable 2 cm below the costal margin, and bowel sounds are normal. Chest radiography shows normal heart size with decreased pulmonary vascularity and no focal consolidation. An electrocardiogram demonstrates sinus tachycardia, right axis deviation, a pure R wave >20 mm in lead V1, and inverted T waves in lead V4. Prostaglandin E1 is initiated. What is the most appropriate next step in management for this patient?
response:
No — the most appropriate next step is urgent balloon (transcatheter) pulmonary valvuloplasty (after immediate echo and pediatric cardiology/cath‑lab activation).

Reasoning: this newborn has signs of critical right ventricular outflow obstruction/valvular pulmonary stenosis with marked cyanosis, low pre/post‑ductal sats, RV hypertrophy on ECG, decreased pulmonary vascularity on CXR and an ejection click plus a harsh systolic ejection murmur. PGE1 is correctly started to maintain ductal pulmonary blood flow; definitive, rapidly effective therapy for valvular critical PS is catheter‑based balloon valvotomy (with surgical palliation reserved if anatomy is not amenable). An urgent echocardiogram is obtained immediately to confirm anatomy prior to catheter intervention.

He was delivered full term via cesarean section for nonreassuring fetal heart tones, with an unremarkable nursery stay. Since discharge, he has been breastfeeding poorly, appearing fatigued and taking longer to feed. His mother reports that he "turns blue when crying," along with rapid breathing and occasional grunting. On examination, the infant has a heart rate of 165 beats per minute, normal blood pressure for his age, and oxygen saturations of 70% preductal and 68% postductal on room air. He appears cyanotic and fatigued, with tachypnea and subcostal retractions. A prominent apical impulse and a thrill are noted on palpation. Auscultation reveals a click after the first heart sound, a fixed, split second heart sound, and a 4/6 crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur heard loudest at the left upper sternal border, extending into diastole. His liver is palpable 2 cm below the costal margin, and bowel sounds are normal. Chest radiography shows normal heart size with decreased pulmonary vascularity and no focal consolidation. An electrocardiogram demonstrates sinus tachycardia, right axis deviation, a pure R wave >20 mm in lead V1, and inverted T waves in lead V4. Prostaglandin E1 is initiated. What is the most appropriate next step in management for this patient?
response: This presentation is most consistent with tetralogy of Fallot with hypercyanotic ("tet") spells. After starting PGE1, the next immediate step is acute stabilization of the cyanotic spell: place the infant in the knee‑to‑chest position, give humidified oxygen, start IV fluids, and administer IV morphine (and give a beta‑blocker such as propranolol or esmolol if the spell persists). Arrange urgent echocardiography/cardiology and surgical consultation afterward.

question: A 29-year-old female patient presents to the office with low back pain lasting five days. She recently began a new job requiring extensive walking, often several miles daily throughout a large facility. The pain is localized to her back without leg radiation, and she reports no traumatic incidents. Her medication history includes only oral contraceptives. Physical examination reveals the following finding: * Normal muscle strength, tone, and reflexes * Left sacral sulcus is deeper than right * Right posterior inferior lateral angle * Left-sided positive seated flexion test What is the most likely diagnosis?
response:
Most likely diagnosis: right-on-left sacral torsion.

Reasoning: A deep left sacral sulcus with a posterior right ILA (opposite-sided sulcus/ILA) indicates an oblique (torsion) pattern. The seated flexion test positive on the left identifies the left oblique axis. Combining those findings gives a sacrum rotated to the right about a left oblique axis — a right-on-left torsion.

question: A 29-year-old female patient presents to the office with low back pain lasting five days. She recently began a new job requiring extensive walking, often several miles daily throughout a large facility. The pain is localized to her back without leg radiation, and she reports no traumatic incidents. Her medication history includes only oral contraceptives. Physical examination reveals the following finding: * Normal muscle strength, tone, and reflexes * Left sacral sulcus is deeper than right * Right posterior inferior lateral angle * Left-sided positive seated flexion test What is the most likely diagnosis?
response:
Most likely diagnosis: left-on-left sacral torsion (L on L), a forward sacral torsion about the left oblique axis.

Reasoning: a left‑positive seated flexion test localizes the dysfunctional oblique axis to the left. The asymmetric findings — deeper left sacral sulcus with the right ILA posterior — are the classic pattern for an L on L torsion (left sacral base anterior/rotated left with the contralateral ILA posterior). Bilateral sacral extension would produce bilateral (not unilateral) deep sulci and posterior ILAs, so it does not fit this asymmetric exam.

question: A 29-year-old female patient presents to the office with low back pain lasting five days. She recently began a new job requiring extensive walking, often several miles daily throughout a large facility. The pain is localized to her back without leg radiation, and she reports no traumatic incidents. Her medication history includes only oral contraceptives. Physical examination reveals the following finding: * Normal muscle strength, tone, and reflexes * Left sacral sulcus is deeper than right * Right posterior inferior lateral angle * Left-sided positive seated flexion test What is the most likely diagnosis?
response:
Most likely diagnosis: Left-on-left sacral torsion (left oblique-axis sacral torsion).

Reasoning: A positive seated‑flexion test on the left indicates the oblique axis is on the left. The left sacral sulcus is deeper and the right ILA is posterior, which fits a sacral base rotated to the left with the opposite ILA posterior — the classic L-on-L torsion pattern, often seen with repetitive gait-related strain.

question: A 29-year-old female patient presents to the office with low back pain lasting five days. She recently began a new job requiring extensive walking, often several miles daily throughout a large facility. The pain is localized to her back without leg radiation, and she reports no traumatic incidents. Her medication history includes only oral contraceptives. Physical examination reveals the following finding: * Normal muscle strength, tone, and reflexes * Left sacral sulcus is deeper than right * Right posterior inferior lateral angle * Left-sided positive seated flexion test What is the most likely diagnosis?
response:
Most likely diagnosis: left-on-left (L on L) sacral torsion.

Reasoning: A torsion shows a deep sacral sulcus and a posterior ILA on opposite sides — here sulcus deeper on the left and ILA posterior on the right. The seated flexion test is positive on the side of the oblique axis (left), and the deep sulcus indicates rotation toward the same side, consistent with an L on L torsion.

question: A 29-year-old female patient presents to the office with low back pain lasting five days. She recently began a new job requiring extensive walking, often several miles daily throughout a large facility. The pain is localized to her back without leg radiation, and she reports no traumatic incidents. Her medication history includes only oral contraceptives. Physical examination reveals the following finding: * Normal muscle strength, tone, and reflexes * Left sacral sulcus is deeper than right * Right posterior inferior lateral angle * Left-sided positive seated flexion test What is the most likely diagnosis?
response: Diagnosis: a sacral torsion — specifically a left-on-left (L on L) sacral torsion (rotation about the left oblique axis).

question: A 15-year-old female visits her pediatrician for a routine check-up. While she is performing well academically, she reports being teased by her peers for not having "hit puberty yet." Her medical history is unremarkable, and she denies any use of illicit substances or medication. Her vital sign are as follows: temperature 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse 80/min, respirations 16/min, blood pressure 156/71 mmHg, and oxygen saturation 98% on room air. On physical examination, she is noted to be at Tanner stage I of development. Which laboratory finding is most likely to be identified in this patient?
response:
Correct — decreased androstenedione (and other sex steroids). 

This presentation (Tanner stage I at age 15 with marked hypertension) is most consistent with 17α-hydroxylase deficiency: impaired sex steroid synthesis → low androstenedione/testosterone/estrogen, low cortisol with compensatory ↑ACTH, and accumulation of mineralocorticoid precursors (eg, ↑11-deoxycorticosterone) causing hypertension and often hypokalemia.

question: A 15-year-old female visits her pediatrician for a routine check-up. While she is performing well academically, she reports being teased by her peers for not having "hit puberty yet." Her medical history is unremarkable, and she denies any use of illicit substances or medication. Her vital sign are as follows: temperature 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse 80/min, respirations 16/min, blood pressure 156/71 mmHg, and oxygen saturation 98% on room air. On physical examination, she is noted to be at Tanner stage I of development. Which laboratory finding is most likely to be identified in this patient?
response:
Most likely: decreased plasma renin activity (with hypokalemia and low sex steroids) — consistent with 17α‑hydroxylase deficiency.

Reasoning: Lack of pubertal development (absent sex steroids) plus severe hypertension at age 15 points to 17α‑hydroxylase deficiency. Accumulation of 11‑deoxycorticosterone produces mineralocorticoid excess → hypertension, hypokalemia and suppression of renin (and often suppressed aldosterone), while cortisol is low and ACTH is elevated and sex steroid synthesis is impaired.

question: A 15-year-old female visits her pediatrician for a routine check-up. While she is performing well academically, she reports being teased by her peers for not having "hit puberty yet." Her medical history is unremarkable, and she denies any use of illicit substances or medication. Her vital sign are as follows: temperature 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse 80/min, respirations 16/min, blood pressure 156/71 mmHg, and oxygen saturation 98% on room air. On physical examination, she is noted to be at Tanner stage I of development. Which laboratory finding is most likely to be identified in this patient?
response:
Most likely finding: markedly elevated FSH (and LH) with low estradiol — consistent with hypergonadotropic hypogonadism (Turner syndrome, 45,X).

Reasoning: Tanner I at age 15 with primary lack of puberty plus hypertension suggests ovarian (gonadal) dysgenesis from Turner syndrome. Streak ovaries fail to make estrogen → loss of negative feedback → high gonadotropins (especially FSH). Coarctation of the aorta or other congenital cardiovascular defects in Turner can explain the hypertension.

question: A 15-year-old female visits her pediatrician for a routine check-up. While she is performing well academically, she reports being teased by her peers for not having "hit puberty yet." Her medical history is unremarkable, and she denies any use of illicit substances or medication. Her vital sign are as follows: temperature 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse 80/min, respirations 16/min, blood pressure 156/71 mmHg, and oxygen saturation 98% on room air. On physical examination, she is noted to be at Tanner stage I of development. Which laboratory finding is most likely to be identified in this patient?
response:
You are correct — the most likely lab finding is decreased androstenedione (low sex steroids).

Reason: A 15-year-old with absent pubertal development (Tanner I) and hypertension fits 17α-hydroxylase deficiency. Impaired 17α-hydroxylase → decreased cortisol and sex steroids (low androstenedione/testosterone/estrogen) and shunting to mineralocorticoid precursors (eg, 11-deoxycorticosterone) → hypertension with suppressed renin. (My earlier reply saying increased renin was incorrect.)

question: A 15-year-old female visits her pediatrician for a routine check-up. While she is performing well academically, she reports being teased by her peers for not having "hit puberty yet." Her medical history is unremarkable, and she denies any use of illicit substances or medication. Her vital sign are as follows: temperature 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse 80/min, respirations 16/min, blood pressure 156/71 mmHg, and oxygen saturation 98% on room air. On physical examination, she is noted to be at Tanner stage I of development. Which laboratory finding is most likely to be identified in this patient?
response: Hypokalemia (low serum potassium) — consistent with 17α-hydroxylase deficiency causing mineralocorticoid excess (elevated 11‑deoxycorticosterone), hypertension, suppressed renin, and absent sex steroid production → lack of secondary sexual development.

question: A 16-year-old female presents with a sore throat and breathing difficulties. She developed cough, congestion, runny nose, low-grade fever, and body aches two days ago. Today, her cough worsened and began producing yellow phlegm. She reports shortness of breath, and her mother noticed a “funny sound” with her breathing that started this afternoon. She has had reduced appetite and minimal fluid intake. She is fully vaccinated, including for Covid-19, and SARS-CoV-2 testing is negative. On examination, her temperature is 39.0°C, heart rate is 110 beats per minute, respiratory rate is 26 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation is 90% on room air. She appears tired, anxious, and ill, with increased work of breathing. Examination reveals nasal congestion but no drooling. Audible inspiratory stridor and moderate intercostal retractions are noted, which do not improve with racemic epinephrine. Breath sounds are present bilaterally without wheezing or rales. The remainder of the physical exam is unremarkable. Which organisms is most likely responsible for this patient’s condition?
response:
Staphylococcus aureus.

Reason: This clinical picture—teen with a viral prodrome who becomes acutely toxic with high fever, inspiratory stridor and increased work of breathing that does not respond to racemic epinephrine—is classic for bacterial tracheitis, most commonly due to Staph aureus (other bacterial pathogens possible). Vaccination and presentation make diphtheria or Hib epiglottitis far less likely.

question: A 16-year-old female presents with a sore throat and breathing difficulties. She developed cough, congestion, runny nose, low-grade fever, and body aches two days ago. On examination, her temperature is 39.0°C, heart rate is 110 beats per minute, respiratory rate is 26 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation is 90% on room air. Audible inspiratory stridor and moderate intercostal retractions are noted, which do not improve with racemic epinephrine. Breath sounds are present bilaterally without wheezing or rales. The remainder of the physical exam is unremarkable. Which organisms is most likely responsible for this patient’s condition?
response:
Conclusion: Staphylococcus aureus (classically the cause of post‑viral bacterial tracheitis).

Reasoning: The history shows a viral prodrome followed by abrupt clinical worsening with high fever, toxic appearance, purulent secretions and inspiratory stridor/retractions that do NOT improve with racemic epinephrine — the classic picture of bacterial tracheitis rather than viral croup or epiglottitis. The most common organism isolated in bacterial tracheitis is S. aureus (including MRSA), although Streptococcus species and H. influenzae can also be implicated.

response:
Staphylococcus aureus.

This presentation is most consistent with bacterial tracheitis — a post‑viral, high‑fever, toxic illness with insidious worsening stridor and respiratory distress that does not respond to racemic epinephrine. The commonest pathogen is S. aureus (with streptococci and nontypeable H. influenzae less commonly implicated); epiglottitis is unlikely given vaccination and absence of drooling.

question: A 16-year-old female presents with a sore throat and breathing difficulties. She developed cough, congestion, runny nose, low-grade fever, and body aches two days ago. On examination, her temperature is 39.0°C, heart rate is 110 beats per minute, respiratory rate is 26 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation is 90% on room air. She appears tired, anxious, and ill, with increased work of breathing. Examination reveals nasal congestion but no drooling. Audible inspiratory stridor and moderate intercostal retractions are noted, which do not improve with racemic epinephrine. Breath sounds are present bilaterally without wheezing or rales. The remainder of the physical exam is unremarkable. Which organisms is most likely responsible for this patient’s condition?
response:
Staphylococcus aureus.

This is most consistent with acute bacterial tracheitis (post‑viral, toxic-looking adolescent with high fever, purulent secretions, inspiratory stridor and increased work of breathing that does not respond to racemic epinephrine). S. aureus (including MRSA) is the common culprit. Corynebacterium diphtheriae is unlikely given full vaccination, absence of a gray pseudomembrane/drooling, and the typical clinical course.

question: A 16-year-old female presents with a sore throat and breathing difficulties. She developed cough, congestion, runny nose, low-grade fever, and body aches two days ago. On examination, her temperature is 39.0°C, heart rate is 110 beats per minute, respiratory rate is 26 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation is 90% on room air. She appears tired, anxious, and ill, with increased work of breathing. Examination reveals nasal congestion but no drooling. Audible inspiratory stridor and moderate intercostal retractions are noted, which do not improve with racemic epinephrine. Breath sounds are present bilaterally without wheezing or rales. The remainder of the physical exam is unremarkable. Which organisms is most likely responsible for this patient’s condition?
response: This picture is most consistent with bacterial tracheitis (postviral) — most commonly caused by Staphylococcus aureus (including MRSA).
